00022 const int MAXCHOLREPS = 1; // Maximum number of times to repeat the 
00023 // cholesky iteration loop before using an SVD

00026 
00027 bool SolveSystem( const Matrix<double>& A, Vector<double>& x, Vector<double>&
00028                   b);
00029    /***
00030        INPUT: Matrix A, vector b, and vector x through which the answer will be returned
00031        OUTPUT: true if clapack returns OK
00032        EFFECT: Calls CLAPACK's dgesv function, to solve the linear system Ax=b,
00033        and stores the solution in x.
00034    ***/
00035 
00036 bool ComputeSVD(const pt_collect &A, pt_collect* U, pt_collect* D,
00037                   pt_collect* VT);
00038    /****
00039    INPUT: Matrix A, to take the SVD of, and pointers to three matrices that will
00040    contain what is returned by the SVD routine. 
00041    its main diagonal.
00042    OUTPUT: true if CLAPACK's dgesvd returns OK.
00043    EFFECT: Calls CLAPACK's dgesvd routine to compute the Singular Value
00044    Decomposition(SVD) of A.  Recall that a SVD of A yields U, D, and V',
00045    s.t. A=U*D* V', where U and V are orthogonal matrices, and D is a diagonal
00046    matrix with the singular values on its main diagonal.
00047   
00048    Borrowed from Chris Siefert's ParamEstimate Class 6/14/99
00049    ****/
00050 
00051 bool ComputeCholesky( const pt_collect & A, pt_collect* U);
00052  /****
00053       INPUT: Matrix A, of which to take the Cholesky factorization and a pointer
00054       to the matrix in which to store U.  A = U`U
00055       OUTPUT: true if CLAPACK's dpotrf returns OK.
00056       EFFECT: Calls CLAPACK's dpotrf routine to compute the Cholesky factorization
00057       of A.  Computes A = U'U where U is upper triangular
00058  ****/
00059 
00060 bool ComputeInverse( const pt_collect & A, pt_collect* INV);
00061  /****
00062       INPUT: Matrix A, of which to find the inverse using the Cholesky
00063       factorization and a pointer to the matrix in which to store the inverse INV.  A INV = I
00064       OUTPUT: true if CLAPACK's dpotri returns OK.
00065       EFFECT: Calls CLAPACK's dpotri routine to compute the Cholesky factorization
00066       of A, and find the inverse from it.
00067       based roughly on Chris Siefert's ComputeSVD code, modified by Anthony Padula
00068  ****/
00069 
00070 #endif

00073 double recipgamma(double x, double *odd, double *even);
00074 /*  Delivers 1/Gamma(1-x);
00075 
00076     x:  double;
00077     entry:  this argument should satisfy -0.5 <= x <= 0.5;
00078        (actually the gamma function is calculated for 1-x, ie. if one wants to
00079        calculate 1/Gamma(1), one has to set x to 0);
00080 
00081     odd:  double *;
00082     exit:   the odd part of 1/Gamma(1-x) divided by (2x);
00083     ie. (1/Gamma(1-x) - 1/Gamma(1+x)) / (2x);
00084 
00085     even:  double *;
00086     exit:   the even part of 1/Gamma(1-x) divided by (2x);
00087     ie. (1/Gamma(1-x) + 1/Gamma(1+x)) / (2x);
00088 
00089 */
00090 
00091 // double gamma(double x); // Stefan: conflicts with mathcalls.h
00092 /* Delivers the value of the gamma function at x.
00093 
00094    x: double;
00095    entry:  the argument; if one of the following three conditions is fulfilled
00096    the overflow will occur:
00097 
00098    1. the argument is too large;
00099    2. the argument is a non-positive integer;
00100    3. the argument is too close to a large ( in absolute value) non-positive
00101    integer.
00102 
00103    functions used: recipgamma, loggamma.
00104 */
00105 
00106 double loggamma( double x);
00107 /* delivers the value of the natural logarithm of the gamma function at x;
00108 
00109    x: double;
00110    entry:  this argument must be positive
00111 
00112 */
00113 
00114 void bessk01( double x, double *k0, double *k1);
00115 /* computes the value of the modified Bessel function of the third kind of order
00116    0 and 1, ie. K_0(x) and K_1(x)
00117 
00118    x: double;
00119    entry:  the argument of the Bessel functions; x>0;
00120 
00121    k0: double *;
00122    exit:   k0 has the value of the modified Bessel function of the third kind of
00123    order zero with argument x;
00124 
00125    k1: double *;
00126    exit:   k1 has the value of the modified Bessel function of the third kind of
00127    order one with argument x;
00128 */
00129 
00130 void bessk( double x, int n, double k[]);
00131 /* Generates an array of modified Bessel functions of the third kind of order j,
00132    K_j(x).
00133 
00134    Calls bessk01 to generate the order zero and order one terms, then computes
00135    higher order terms by recursion:
00136 
00137    K_{j+1}(x) = K_{j-1}(x)+(2*j/x)*K_{j}(x)
00138 
00139 
00140    x: double;
00141    entry:  the argument of the Bessel functions; x>0
00142 
00143    n: int;
00144    entry:  the upper bound of the indices of array k; n>=0;
00145 
00146    k: double k[0:n];
00147    exit:   k[j] is the value of the modified Bessel function of the third kind
00148    of order j with argument x, j=0,...,n.
00149 */
00150 
00151 void nonexpbessk01( double x, double *k0, double * k1);
00152 /* computes the value of the modified Bessel function of the third kind of order
00153    0 and 1, ie. K_0(x) and K_1(x), multiplied by e^x.
00154 
00155    x: double;
00156    entry:  the argument of the Bessel functions; x>0;
00157 
00158    k0: double *;
00159    exit:   k0 has the value of the modified Bessel function of the third kind of
00160    order zero with argument x, multiplied by e^x;
00161 
00162    k1: double *;
00163    exit:   k1 has the value of the modified Bessel function of the third kind of
00164    order one with argument x, multiplied by e^x;
00165 */
00166
